utterances: And that came out recently where he testified to Congress previously that there was no significant internal debate about that wiretapping program.
And now, as we know, not only we're going through significant debate as to the period the program was operating under the rules that a pretty conservative Attorney General was very…
John Ashcroft, yeah.
…right, was very, very concerned about.

And by saying, you know, that there was no significant debate at Congress, I mean, to me, I don't know if perjury is the right term when you mislead or lie to Congress, but it seems to me it's an impeachable offense.
And if you like at the ways he misled Congress both in that (unintelligible) and then in the federal prosecutor - you know, personally, the guy ought to be impeached.
Because clearly, the president is never going to let this guy go.
He's been with him for too long.
He's been involved in everything from Texas until today.
Well, just to suggest to Mike, you know, if he can get 60 votes for a vote of no-confidence in a meaningless vote, impeachment seems a long stretch.
But let me ask Ken Rudin.
He knows more about this than I do.
Well, the problem is that - several things are a problem.
The Democrats are going after Gonzales on all these things you mentioned, not only the U.S.
attorneys, but, you know, the abuses hat Guantanamo, the domestic surveillance that has certainly, as we've seen in testimonies, there were internal questions.
Gonzales' testimony before the Senate has always been one of convolution and contradictions.
He has never been accused of breaking any law.
Nothing, as Tony Snow said today, that no charges, he's never broken any law.

But the real story to me maybe the fact that as if Gonzales where to go, to leave or be fired, whom does President Bush get to replace him and what kind of a nominee could he pick that a Democratic-controlled Senate would confirm?
Obviously, he wouldn't go the moderate route.
We've seen with his Supreme Court choices that President Bush wants to have a conservative administration and he's comfortable with conservative choices.
Would a Democratic-led Senate go for that?
And that's, I think, one of the real questions and one of the reasons why Gonzales is staying as long as he has.
The fight to come might be worse than the fight that he's got.
It might be.
Yeah.
Right.
Mike, thanks very much for the call.
Thanks.
Let's go now to - this is Danny(ph).
Danny from Kentucky.
DANNY, (Caller): Hello
Hi.
Yes.
I'd like to talk about the changes that Mitch McConnell's power.
He's not only become the minority leader, but also, he backed the local Anne Northup down here for the House of Representatives.
He - she lost.
He also backed her for the governor primary and the Republican.
And she lost that also.
So I'll take my answer off the air.
And Mitch McConnell, of course, up for reelection this coming cycle.
Why I didn't - I still haven't seen a top tier Democrat running against McConnell.
But it looks like the Republicans could very well lose the governorship, but they waited 40 or 35 years to take Governor Ernie Fletcher.
I think one of the reasons that Mitch McConnell backed Anne Northup for governor is that they feel about the incumbent Republican Governor Ernie Fletcher is damaged goods, could lose in November.
I don't think it's a fault with McConnell and McConnell's choice.
But the fact that Fletcher is just, you know, so vulnerable to defeat.
As far as McConnell himself goes, he's very popular among his Republican colleagues in the Senate and more so than Bill Frist was, the previous Republican leader.
And McConnell should sail out to reelection in November.
And long as we're talking about Republicans.
We have a minute left, Ken.
And there are new figures out, a WMUR/CNN poll on Republicans in New Hampshire.
Some interesting results too.

Well, the big news, I guess, is something that we've been seeing for quite sometime, is that Mitt Romney, who's been spending freely, advertising freely heavily in New Hampshire, has gone from back of the pack, certainly a weak third in the pack, to leading in the polls again.
You know, polls, eight months out is kind of crazy.
But the fact is that the previous frontrunners, Giuliani and John McCain, seemed to be falling down.
And McCain - and Romney, who's spending as freely as he his, he could be very well be the nominee.
You know, forget about what his contradictions in his past, the so-called flip-flops.
He is really winning over a lot of Republicans who just like a fresh face there.
But in 15 seconds, what about the new fresh face, Fred Thompson?
Well, I have a feeling right now, Fred Thompson is as popular as he'll ever be.
Once he gets in the race, we may not see him as dynamic as he is on ""Law & Order.
Well, Ken Rudin, thanks very much.
And let's do it again next Wednesday, Ken Rudin, thanks very much.
And let's do it again next Wednesday.
Whenever day this is.
Thanks, Neal.
Ken Rudin is NPR's political editor.
He also writes the weekly Political Junkie column and has a regular politics column podcast called It's All Politics.
And you can find both of them at npr.org.
I'm Neal Conan.
NPR News in Washington.

The U.S.
is already spending 2.5 trillion over the next decade.
So this would be a 40 percent jump.

A trillion dollars is the kind of money most of us will never get the chance to blow.
So it's sort of hard to imagine what a trillion-dollar spending spree might actually look like.
Here's one way to picture it.

DWIGHT D.
EISENHOWER: We are pushing ahead with a great road program.

Even as a child, she was a hardscrabble sort of Lubbock girl.
The art on her new album shows a tattooed and smiling woman tumbling upside down.
Amanda Shires is fragile and tough at the same time, and she's in a better place now.
Her finger's healed, and she got married this spring.
But that hard year laid the foundation for a new album called ""Down Fell the Doves.
I spoke with Amanda Shires from her tour stop in Buffalo.
And we started at the beginning, and the story of what led her to the violin as a 10-year-old.
I went with my dad to a pawnshop in Mineral Wells, Texas, called AD Garretts.
And he was in there shopping for a new hunting knife because he wanted one with a compass on it.
And I just saw this fiddle hanging on the wall, and I just asked if we could look at it, and he said yeah.
Pretty much just begged him to get it for me.
It was $65 - which was, for us, a lot of money.
He said if I - if he got that for me, I'd have to learn how to play it.
And I said I would do that.
And then it just started from there.
After that, I went home from my dad's, in the summer, to my mom's, in Lubbock, Texas.
And she started me in orchestra and private violin lessons.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""A SONG FOR LEONARD COHEN"")
There's another song here that pays homage to someone I also just grew up on and love, and this is ""A Song for Leonard Cohen."" Let's hear a little bit of it.
Oh, man.
I'm excited about me and you.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""A SONG FOR LEONARD COHEN"")
(Singing) I wish that I could buy you a drink, and then more, and then five.
I'd get you drunk, and it'd get me out going all week or just this one night...
So what is Leonard Cohen's influence on your work?
Well, I started appreciating Leonard Cohen when I started reading his poetry.
I think I just love words so much that I just - I don't know; I fell in love with his.
And then I started reading more about him and listening to his music.
I like the place that he came from.
I like that he is studied in poetry, and then switched over to music and had a little problem with stage fright.
And I like that he played for mental hospitals and things like that.
There's a lot of cool things about him.
And he's very handsome; I don't know if you've seen him.
Yeah, I have.
And I would agree.
He can dance like a madman.
Uh-huh.
In that weathered kind of way - I think I can say that, yeah.
I also read that you have a Leonard Cohen verse tattooed on your arm.
Yes, I do.
Now, this is something I want to talk to him about because I've read in some biographies about him that he doesn't think that ""Hallelujah"" should be covered anymore.
So...
And that's the verse you've got.
